bwwExcerpt: “Prayer for the French Republic” addresses, with nuance, detail and understated passion, the tensions and the connections between history and current events. While it tells of a particular family, it illuminates the troubles of all people caught up in the turbulent tides of history—as everyone in a sense is—even if some face graver danger than others.

garbageFullText:
https://www.wsj.com/articles/prayer-for-the-french-republic-review-antisemitism-joshua-harmon-david-cromer-anthony-edwards-broadway-0732206e

Molly Ranson, Francis Benhamou, Nael Nacer, Aria Shahghasemi, Betsy Aidem and Anthony Edwards Jeremy DanielIn Joshua Harmon’s “Prayer for the French Republic,” a Jewish family in France faces the wrenching decision of whether to abandon their established and accomplished lives to leave the country—and possibly save themselves from persecution, or worse.

Manhattan Theatre Club at the Samuel J. Friedman Theatre, 261 W. 47th St., New York, $79-$199, 212-239-6200, closes March 3

You might assume the play is set during World War II. But while Mr. Harmon’s inexpressibly moving drama does include scenes from the 1940s, the family in question is grappling with the question of exile, to Israel, in the 21st century.

The play, easily the finest of the Broadway season so far, was first produced two years ago by Manhattan Theatre Club off-Broadway. Even then it was grimly topical. Now the play resounds with a chilling immediacy that lends it even greater and more unsettling power.

It is an unhappy coincidence that the production, featuring largely the same flawless cast and the same expert director, David Cromer, returns as the world confronts a spike in antisemitism; but perhaps we can feel grateful that this beautifully realized staging so trenchantly addresses the here and now—however uncomfortable that here and now is.

Copyright ©2025 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. 87990cbe856818d5eddac44c7b1cdeb8
